ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot of writing techniques to use in all types of writing, specifically in creative non-fiction.
I developed my writing skills and learned how to write in different styles based off the authors we read.

For context, I was a Junior when I took this course and had spent much of my time in college taking writing courses, and I still learned a ton from this class. Craig did a great job of teaching us how to identify what the writers that we were reading were doing well and how to integrate these techniques into our own writing. I also ended up learning a lot about how to write humor effectively which I had never done before and was incredibly fun.

I personally am not a big creative writer but this course helped me become more comfortable with writing about my personal experiences and utilizing different writing techniques to improve the delivery.
Learned many creative nonfiction writing techniques.
Learning how to write solid concrete sentences. Reading texts from good writers and applying their strategies into our own writing.
I learned how to write creative nonfiction essays. I learned and honed the techniques of creative writing, including anaphora, epistrophe, anadiplosis, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths of this course are how each section of the course builds on one another and what techniques you learn in one unit you can use in others to improve your writing. I can't think of any weaknesses.
Really good readings but not a lot of feedback on essays.

The strengths of this course are that it forces you to write a lot which really pushes you to improve your writing. You also read a lot of great essays. One way this course could be improved is if there was an upperclassmen seminar. The required revisions are great. They really force you to improve your writing and Craig gives great feedback. As a Junior, I felt like I was approaching the course from a very different perspective than many of my classmates who were just coming out of high school. A lot of english 120 is about processing your life through writing and I feel like my experience could have improved if I had been with a group that I felt was at the same stage of college/life. Also I just has way more writing experience than anybody else, so my starting point was different.
This course covered many different topics and had readings that went along with each topic. The structure and organization was very strong. I wouldn't change anything about the course.
Engaging class readings although we couldn't always cover them all.
I think we read a lot of text, but we didn't go too deep into most of them.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes definitely. It's such an enjoyable writing credit, and I got so much out of it.
Yes good readings, loved my teacher, and makes you work on your writing skills and be creative.
For sure. This is a great class. Whatever your starting point, you will learn a lot a grow as a writer.
Yes I would recommend this course. This course helps you expand your way of thinking.
Yes! This was an incredible enjoyable course for students who enjoy writing or want to improve.
Yes, 120 is good for learning how to convey and express your own ideas.
Absolutely - very fun and stimulating course.
